quests.name: The Trojan War
quests.description: Led the Myrmidons as the greatest Greek warrior against Troy in the ten-year siege
quests.outcome: Killed Hector but died before Troy's fall

quests.name: Avenging Patroclus
quests.description: Returned to battle after his beloved companion's death at Hector's hands
quests.outcome: Slew Hector and dragged his body around Troy's walls

quests.name: The Funeral Games for Patroclus
quests.description: Organized elaborate athletic competitions to honor his fallen companion
quests.outcome: Demonstrated Greek ideals of heroic honor in death

quests.name: Battle with the River Scamander
quests.description: Fought the river god himself when Scamander rose against him for filling the waters with Trojan dead
quests.outcome: Saved by Hephaestus who dried the river with divine fire

displayName: Achilles - Swift-Footed Hero of the Trojan War
feats: Slew Hector, greatest champion of Troy, in single combat
Defeated the Ethiopian king Memnon, son of Eos
Captured twelve cities by sea and eleven by land during the Trojan War
Killed Troilus, son of Priam, at Apollo's temple
Routed the entire Trojan army single-handedly after Patroclus' death
Fought and nearly defeated the river god Scamander

description: Achilles (Greek: Achilleus) stands as the greatest warrior of Greek mythology and the central figure of Homer's Iliad, embodying both the glory and tragedy of the heroic ideal. Born to the sea-nymph Thetis and the mortal king Peleus, Achilles was destined from birth for a fateful choice: a long, obscure life or a short life of eternal glory. His mother, knowing his fate, attempted to make him immortal by dipping him in the River Styx, holding him by his heel - which remained vulnerable. Raised by the centaur Chiron on Mount Pelion, Achilles learned the arts of war, medicine, and music, emerging as the most formidable warrior of his generation. When the Greeks sailed for Troy to reclaim Helen, Achilles initially hid on Skyros disguised as a girl (according to later traditions), but Odysseus discovered him, and he joined the expedition knowing he would never return home. For nine years Achilles was the Greeks' greatest asset, capturing cities and earning renown. In the tenth year, however, King Agamemnon seized Briseis, a woman Achilles had claimed as a war prize, and the hero withdrew from battle in rage. His absence proved catastrophic - the Trojans pushed the Greeks back to their ships. Only when his beloved companion Patroclus fell to Hector while wearing Achilles' armor did the hero return to war. His grief transformed into terrible wrath; clad in new divine armor forged by Hephaestus, Achilles slaughtered Trojans by the hundreds, fought the river god Scamander, and finally cornered and killed Hector, dragging his body behind his chariot for days. Yet even in vengeance, Achilles' humanity emerged when he returned Hector's body to King Priam, recognizing their shared grief. Achilles himself fell soon after, struck in his vulnerable heel by an arrow shot by Paris but guided by Apollo. His armor sparked a fatal dispute between Ajax and Odysseus. Achilles represents the archetype of the tragic hero - supremely gifted, knowing his fate, choosing glory over long life, and ultimately undone by the very passion that made him great.

metadata.historicalPeriod: Bronze Age (Mycenaean period, c. 1600-1100 BCE in mythological setting), Homeric poems c. 8th century BCE

abilities: Near-invulnerability - Protected by Styx waters except for his heel
Supreme combat prowess - Unmatched warrior of his generation
Divine heritage - Son of Thetis granting superhuman qualities
Prophetic awareness - Knew his fate and chose glory
Medical knowledge - Trained by Chiron in healing arts
Musical skill - Played the lyre, taught by Chiron

divine.description: A Nereid (sea-nymph), daughter of Nereus, who could shapeshift and foresaw her son's fate

mortal.description: King of the Myrmidons in Phthia, hero who captured Thetis despite her transformations

parentage.heritage: Demigod - Son of a goddess and mortal king, destined for glory and early death

death.manner: Shot by Paris with an arrow guided by Apollo to his vulnerable heel
death.aftermath: His armor was contested by Ajax and Odysseus; his shade dwelt in the underworld

themes: The choice between glory and longevity
The bonds of love and friendship (philia)
The tragedy of knowing one's fate
symbolism.vulnerability: Achilles' heel became proverbial for a fatal weakness in an otherwise invulnerable entity
